properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.
  • Significant rainfall occurred over the past week in the Bendigo Creek Catchment. 
  • Widespread moderate flooding is occurring along the Bendigo Creek downstream of Minto.
  • These floodwaters continue to move downstream affecting locations including Tandarra, Dingee, Prairie and Mitiamo with a peak expected at Mitiamo Friday afternoon.
  • Flooding is expected to peak at Pyramid Hill over the coming days, and Ghow (Kow) Swamp into early next week. 
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do: 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Farmers should moving livestock and machinery away from flooded areas.
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • A small number of properties are likely to be impacted and possibly become isolated.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Mosquitoes will breed in warm stagnant water after flood waters recede. For more information on protecting yourself please visit Better Health: Mozzies
Road Closures:
A number of roads are impacted by floodwater. 
  • The Bendigo-Tennyson Road is closed between Kamarooka and Miloo.  
  • The Dingee-Rochester Road is closed between Queen Street and Dunn Road.
  • A number of other roads are closed. For more information go to VicTraffic
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 15/01/2024 01:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
WATCH & ACT - RIVERINE FLOOD - Avoid the Flooded Area
Incident Location: Bendigo and Bullock Creeks
Issue Date: Friday 12 January 2024, 01:55 pm
Next Update: Monday 15 January 2024, 01:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32430/moreinfo

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.
- Significant rainfall occurred over the past week in the Bendigo Creek Catchment.  
- Widespread moderate flooding is occurring along the Bendigo Creek downstream of Minto.
- These floodwaters continue to move downstream affecting locations including Tandarra, Dingee, Prairie and Mitiamo with a peak expected at Mitiamo Friday afternoon.
- Flooding is expected to peak at Pyramid Hill over the coming days, and Ghow (Kow) Swamp into early next week. 


Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham.

Recent rainfall over the Campaspe and Goulburn River catchments resulted in major flooding at Rochester (Campaspe River) and minor flooding at Shepparton (Goulburn River).

Floodwaters from the Goulburn and Campaspe River catchments may cause minor flooding along the Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir and Barham during the week of 14 January. 

Murray River downstream of Torrumarry to Barham:
  • The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir is currently at 6.32 metres and steady, below the minor flood level. It may reach may reach the minor flood level (7.30m) during the week of 14 January. Further rises are possible.
  • The Murray River at Barham is currently at 5.27 metres and steady, below the minor flood level. It may reach the minor flood level (5.50 m) during the week of 14 January. Further rises are possible.
  • River levels upstream of Torrumbarry and Barham have not yet peaked. Peak river levels are used to calculate downstream river levels and when peaks may occur. When upstream peaks occur, the forecast downstream river levels and timing will be updated.
  • River levels at Echuca are likely to remain below the minor flood level.

    This warning is for communities in Victoria. Floods have different impacts on either side of the Murray River. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, visit www.hazardwatch.gov.au. Always follow advice from your State’s emergency services

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • High river levels adjacent to Gunbower Island are inundating camping areas and affecting access to and via River Track. Roads and visitor sites are temporarily closed until floodwaters recede and sites can be assessed as safe. For more information visit Parks Victoria.
  • Other camping areas and Caravan parks may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 15/01/2024 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Always follow advice from your State’s emergency services Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.

  • Moderate flooding is possible at McCoys Bridge during Sunday or Monday. 
  • No significant rainfall was recorded across the Goulburn River catchment in the 24 hours to 9:00 am Saturday and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. 
  • A minor flood peak has been observed at Shepparton late Friday night. The river level is slowly easing, however a small renewed rise is possible overnight Saturday as remaining flows from upstream tributaries may arrive. This possible renewed rise is expected to be below the peak level (10.34 m) observed on Friday evening. Flood waters will then approach McCoys Bridge during Sunday into Monday, where moderate flooding remains possible.
  • Releases from Lake Eildon are at 7500 ML/day, below the minor flood level. 

Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton:
Moderate flooding may occur along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton. 

The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is currently at 8.00 metres and rising slowly, below the minor flood level. The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge may exceed the minor flood level (9.00 m) overnight Saturday into Sunday. The river level may peak near the moderate flood level (10.00 metres) during Sunday or Monday.

This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 10:26 am Saturday 13 January 2024. 
Prepare for flooding now. 
Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by flooding.
What you should do:
 
  • Check out the Shepparton-Mooroopna-Kialla Local Flood Guide for more detailed information  www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/greater-shepparton-city-council
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Rising floodwater can be dangerous. Be aware of water levels rising near you.
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground if still safe to do so.
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are camping close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, well away from waterways.

If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home and sheds is likely to occur in some locations.
  • A small number of properties may be possibility become cut off or isolated 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams. Floodwater should stay within the river channel until it reaches close to the Murray River.
  • Moira Shire have advised local caravan Parks and are in contact with the Barmah Community.
  • Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
Main Road Closures:
  • McCoys Bridge on the Murray Valley Highway (B400) is currently open with a 40 km/h speed limit in place
  • Yambuna Bridge Road closed at both sides of the river
  • Check the VicTraffic website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au for any new road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2024 01:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
WATCH & ACT - RIVERINE FLOOD - Prepare Now
Incident Location: Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton
Issue Date: Saturday 13 January 2024, 05:30 pm
Next Update: Sunday 14 January 2024, 01:30 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32451/moreinfo

This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.

- Moderate flooding is possible at McCoys Bridge during Sunday or Monday. 
- No significant rainfall was recorded across the Goulburn River catchment in the 24 hours to 9:00 am Saturday and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. 
- A minor flood peak has been observed at Shepparton late Friday night. The river level is slowly easing, however a small renewed rise is possible overnight Saturday as remaining flows from upstream tributaries may arrive. This possible renewed rise is expected to be below the peak level (10.34 m) observed on Friday evening. Flood waters will then approach McCoys Bridge during Sunday into Monday, where moderate flooding remains possible.
- Releases from Lake Eildon are at 7500 ML/day, below the minor flood level. 


Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton:
Moderate flooding may occur along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton. 

The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is currently at 8.00 metres and rising slowly, below the minor flood level. The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge may exceed the minor flood level (9.00 m) overnight Saturday into Sunday. The river level may peak near the moderate flood level (10.00 metres) during Sunday or Monday. 

This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 10:26 am Saturday 13 January 2024. 

Prepare for flooding now. 
Take actions to protect your life and property against potential hazards caused by flooding.

properties.name: Warning
properties.location: Areas near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Tremont and Ferny Creek
properties.webBody:
This Warning is being issued for areas near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Ferny Creek.

  • A landslide has occurred in the area near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Ferny Creek.
  • The landslide is approximately 40 metres wide, 70 metres long and 4 metres deep.
  • Emergency works are continuing. 
  • This Warning replaces the Warning issued at 6:50 pm on Friday 12 January 2024.
Stay safe by avoiding damaged buildings, fallen trees and powerlines, blocked or damaged roads. Be aware of other hazards caused by the landslide.
What you should do:
If another landslide occurs, act quickly:
  • If you are outside during a landside, move quickly and keep clear of embankments, trees, powerlines and poles.
  • If you are inside, move to the part of building that is furthest away from the approaching landslide and take shelter under a table or bench.
Avoid the area:
  • Stay away from the impacted area to allow emergency services to help affected communities.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Driving:
  • Plan your trip in advance - travel may take longer due to closed roads and poor driving conditions.
Impacts in your area:

The landslide has resulted in:
  • The Mount Dandenong Tourist Road is closed between Churchill Drive and Mast Gully Road and may remain closed for some time. For more information on road closures go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Properties and structures have been impacted.
  • Fallen power lines and power disruptions. 
  • Fallen trees and branches.
  • Dangerous road conditions.
  • Other impacts to essential services including natural gas and water leaks.
  • Exposed asbestos from building materials within the landslide site.
  • Public Transport has been impacted by the landslide. You should check www.ptv.vic.gov.au/live-travel-updates for the latest updates on services.

Emergency works are continuing:
  • Landslide hazard and safety assessments by engineers are ongoing.
  • Power infrastructure has been repaired. 
  • Emergency services have isolated the natural gas leak and made the area safe. 
  • Asbestos removal works are planned to occur over the weekend (Saturday 13 January - Sunday 14 January) to deal with asbestos hazards and further dangerous trees in the landslide site.
  • Removal of the dangerous trees will continue once the asbestos removal has concluded. This will begin again on Monday at this stage.
  • There will be power disruptions during hazardous tree mitigation works. 
  • An assessment of the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road condition is planned to occur once tree works are complete.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2024 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#viclandslide).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Pyramid Creek downstream of Ghow (Kow) Swamp
properties.webBody:
This Flood Advice is being issued for Pyramid Creek downstream of Ghow (Kow) Swamp.

  • Minor flood impacts are likely to occur along Pyramid Creek downstream of Ghow (Kow) Swamp.
  • Goulburn-Murray Water have increased the flows from Ghow (Kow) Swamp to Box Creek from 1000 megalitres per day to 1500 megalitres per day for flood mitigation.
  • Flows will likely continue at a heightened rate over the coming weeks.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Landholders between Ghow (Kow) Swamp and Box Creek are advised to move machinery and cattle to higher ground, and ensure that any privately owned levees are of an adequate standard. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes. 
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

For more information on the increased flows from Ghow (Kow) Swamp to Box Creek, contact Goulburn-Murray Water on 1800 013 357.
Impacts in your area:
  • Floodwater will generally be contained within the banks along Pyramid Creek.
  • There may be some locations where floodwater impacts private land adjacent to the creek.
  • Emergency Services and contractors are undertaking works to repair a number of priority breaches. Please stay clear of machinery operating in the area.
  • Not all breaches will be repaired. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service 

The next update is expected by 15/01/2024 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (Vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Craigieburn.
  • There is a building fire in Smeaton Court Craigieburn . 
  • Firefighters are currently responding to this fire. 
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
  • You may see or smell smoke. 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.   

Health information: 
  • If you need medical advice for exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. 
  • Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).    
  • Smoke information: Smoke can affect people’s health. For more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/smoke-and-your-health    
Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Goulburn River Murchison to Shepparton.

  • Minor flood peak observed at Shepparton late Friday, with smaller renewed rise possible overnight Saturday into Sunday.
  • Moderate flooding possible at McCoys bridge during Sunday or Monday
  • No significant rainfall was recorded across the Goulburn River catchment in the 24 hours to 9:00 am Saturday and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

A minor flood peak has been observed at Shepparton late Friday night. The river level is slowly easing, however a small renewed rise is possible overnight Saturday as remaining flows from upstream tributaries may arrive. This possible renewed rise is expected to be below the peak level (10.34 m) observed on Friday evening. 

Flood waters will then approach McCoys Bridge during Sunday into Monday, where moderate flooding remains possible.

Releases from Lake Eildon are at 7500 ML/day, below the minor flood level.

Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton. 

  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton peaked at 10.34 metres around 10:00 pm Friday with minor flooding and is currently at 10.20 metres and steady. 
  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton is expected to remain above the minor flood level (9.50 m) overnight Saturday into Sunday, with a small renewed rise possible as flow from upstream tributaries arrives. 
  • This possible renewed peak is expected to be below the peak observed on Friday night.

This Advice replaces the Minor Flood Warning issued at 10.25 am Saturday 13 January, 2024
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Check out the SES Murchison and Shepparton-Mooroopna-Kialla Local Flood Guides for more flood information: https://www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/greater-shepparton-city-council
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding may still exist in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Low-lying riverside Caravan parks and camping grounds may still be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.

At Minor flood level on the Shepparton Gauge:
  • Watt Road and Raftery Road likely to flood.

The Peter Ross Edwards Causeway (Midland Hwy) has been reduced in speed to 40 kilometres an hour due to wildlife and pedestrians.

Main road closures:
Murchison: 
  • Watson St Murchison
  • Old Weir Road, from Station Street to Salas Road, Murchison
  • Station Street, Willoughby Street, Murchison to Charles Lane, Murchison

Toolamba:
  • Bridge Road between Newnham Road and Wren Street
  • Mcnamara Rd between Cummins Rd and Pogue Rd

Mooroopna:
  • Watt Road between McLennan Street, Mooroopna and Riverview Drive Kialla

Shepparton:
  • Tom Collins Drive from Welsford St to just past the roundabout

Kialla:
  • Raftery Road from Edgewater Road to Sevens Creek Drive 
  • Mitchell Road between Goulburn Valley Highway and Archer Street
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2024 01:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

For health information and support contact the below organisations:
Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. 
Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. 
Kids Helpline on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. 
SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Goulburn River Murchison to Shepparton

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Goulburn River Murchison to Shepparton.

- Minor flood peak observed at Shepparton late Friday, with smaller renewed rise possible overnight Saturday into Sunday.
- Moderate flooding possible at McCoys bridge during Sunday or Monday
- No significant rainfall was recorded across the Goulburn River catchment in the 24 hours to 9:00 am Saturday and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.


A minor flood peak has been observed at Shepparton late Friday night. The river level is slowly easing, however a small renewed rise is possible overnight Saturday as remaining flows from upstream tributaries may arrive. This possible renewed rise is expected to be below the peak level (10.34 m) observed on Friday evening. 
Flood waters will then approach McCoys Bridge during Sunday into Monday, where moderate flooding remains possible.

Releases from Lake Eildon are at 7500 ML/day, below the minor flood level. 
Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton. 

- The Goulburn River at Shepparton peaked at 10.34 metres around 10:00 pm Friday with minor flooding and is currently at 10.20 metres and steady. 
- The Goulburn River at Shepparton is expected to remain above the minor flood level (9.50 m) overnight Saturday into Sunday, with a small renewed rise possible as flow from upstream tributaries arrives. 
- This possible renewed peak is expected to be below the peak observed on Friday night. 


This Advice replaces the Minor Flood Warning issued at 10.25 am Saturday 13 January, 2024 

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Wyuna East.

  • There is a haystack fire at Wilson Road, Wyuna East. 
  • Haystack fires are not likely to spread into grassland but do generate a lot of smoke.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
  • Firefighters are monitoring this fire.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to cal VicEmergency
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Smoke information: Smoke can affect people’s health. For more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/health/videos/Smoke-and-your-health-protect-your-health.  Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang.

  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Loddon River downstream of Loddon Weir.
  • The Loddon River at Appin South is currently at 2.93m and slowly rising, with minor flooding.
  • The Loddon River at Appin South may peak near 3.00m overnight Saturday into Sunday and is likely to remain above the minor flood level (2.80m) during the weekend.
  • No significant rainfall has been observed across the Loddon catchment since 9am Friday and no significant rainfall is forecast for next few days.
  • At this stage flooding is not expected to extend downstream to Kerang. Forecasts will be updated as peaks are observed at Appin South from the weekend.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
  • Mosquitoes will breed in warm stagnant water after flood waters recede. For more information on protecting yourself please visit Better Health: Mosquitoes.
Road closures:
  • A number roads are closed in and around Skinners Flat, Woosang, Borung, Mysia, Barraport, Appin and Tragowel.
  • Other local roads may be closed or impacted by floodwater. For the latest information please check VicRoads - VicTraffic.
  • Never drive through floodwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River downstream of Wandocka:

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUES TO SLOWLY EASE AT SALE WHARF

Minor flooding is occurring at Sale Wharf, where the river level is easing.

In the 24 hrs to 9:00 am Saturday, no significant rainfall was observed across the Thomson River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the remainder of Saturday.

Thomson River downstream of Wandocka:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Thomson River downstream of Wandocka. 

The Thomson River at Sale Wharf is currently at 2.44 metres and slowly falling, with minor flooding. The Thomson River at Sale Wharf is likely to fall below the minor flood level (2.40 m) during Saturday.


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides – be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2024 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Seven Creeks Downstream of Euroa.

Minor flooding easing at Kialla West.

Rainfall during last weekend and into this week caused river level rises and minor flooding along the Seven Creeks. Kialla West peaked below moderate flood level Friday morning and river levels are easing. The river level is likely to fall below the minor flood level during Saturday.

No significant rainfall has been observed across the catchment since late Monday. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa:
Minor flooding is easing along the Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa.

The Seven Creeks at Kialla West peaked at 4.83 metres around 10:00 am Friday with minor flooding and is currently at 4.60 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Seven Creeks at Kialla West is likely to fall below the minor flood level (4.50 m) during Saturday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

Check out the Shepparton-Mooroopna-Kialla Local Flood Guide https://www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/greater-shepparton-city-council for more detailed flood information.

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
For health information and support contact the below organisations: 
Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. 
Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. 
Kids Helpline on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. 
SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Goulburn River - Seymour to Murchison.

  • Minor flood peak observed at Shepparton late Friday, with smaller renewed rise possible overnight Saturday into Sunday. 
  • Moderate flooding possible at McCoys bridge during Sunday or Monday
  • No significant rainfall was recorded across the Goulburn River catchment in the 24 hours to 9:00 am Saturday and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

A minor flood peak has been observed at Shepparton late Friday night. The river level is slowly easing, however a small renewed rise is possible overnight Saturday as remaining flows from upstream tributaries may arrive. This possible renewed rise is expected to be below the peak level (10.34 m) observed on Friday evening. 
Flood waters will then approach McCoys Bridge during Sunday into Monday, where moderate flooding remains possible.

Releases from Lake Eildon are at 7500 ML/day, below the minor flood level.

Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River Seymour to Shepparton.

  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton peaked at 10.34 metres around 10:00 pm Friday with minor flooding and is currently at 10.20 metres and steady. 
  • The Goulburn River at Shepparton is expected to remain above the minor flood level (9.50 m) overnight Saturday into Sunday, with a small renewed rise possible as flow from upstream tributaries arrives. 
  • This possible renewed peak is expected to be below the peak observed on Friday night.

This Advice replaces the Minor Flood warning issued at 10.26 pm Saturday 13 January, 2024. 
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Check out the Murchison Local Flood Guide for detailed flood information  https://www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/greater-shepparton-city-council and the Seymour Local Flood Guide: https://www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/mitchell-shire-council 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Goulburn Valley Water GVW advise that drinking water in Nagambie is safe to drink. Treated water is being trucked in to support local supplies. GVW are keeping locals advised of the situation via sms messages and website updates.
  • High river levels and potential flooding may still remain in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Low lying Caravan parks and camping areas close to the river may still be flooded.
Main Road Closures:
  • Popples Lane near Seymour is CLOSED due to flooding and road damage
  • Old Weir Road, from Station Street to Salas Road, Murchison
  • Station Street, Willoughby Street, Murchison to Charles Lane, Murchison
  • Ashes Bridge Road, Seymour-Pyalong Road, Hilldene to Tallarook-Pyalong Road, Sugarloaf Creek
  • Local roads may still be closed and low bridges may be underwater. For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 14/01/2024 01:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

For health information and support contact the below organisations: 
Lifeline on www.lifeline.org.au or phone 13 11 14. 
Beyond Blue on www.beyondblue.org.au or phone 1300 224 636. 
Kids Helpline on www.kidshelp.com.au or phone 1800 551 800. 
SANE Australia on www.sane.org or phone 1800 187 263.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • There is a building fire on Queen Street, Ararat.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 31/01/2024 04:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

- High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 



Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran.

  • Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 10:10 AM 2 January 2024. 
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings and providing advice to relevant authorities. 
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 16/01/2024 02:40 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - DANGEROUS ANIMAL - Avoid the Area
Incident Location: Cape Conran
Issue Date: Tuesday 09 January 2024, 02:39 pm
Next Update: Tuesday 16 January 2024, 02:40 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32302/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran.

- Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
- A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
- While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area. 
- This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 10:10 AM 2 January 2024. 


Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
